case_name: Taylor v. ConverseNow Technologies, Inc.
ai_relevance: AI phone-order assistants allegedly intercepted and recorded customer calls without consent, violating CIPA.
ai_presence: The case centers on ConverseNow’s use of AI technology to process restaurant phone orders. ConverseNow allegedly deployed AI assistants to handle incoming customer calls, during which the AI intercepted, recorded, and analyzed the conversations. The complaint asserts that these recorded calls were then used to train and improve ConverseNow’s AI software, all without informing or obtaining consent from the customers. The court treated ConverseNow, which uses AI to capture and process the calls for its own software enhancement, as a third party under the capability approach when evaluating the alleged CIPA violations.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual consumer and class representative
parties.defendant_description: Technology company providing AI phone assistants

claims.claim: Violation of California Invasion of Privacy Act for unauthorized interception of communications via AI phone assistants.
claims.legal_basis: California Penal Code § 631 (wiretapping and interception of communications).
claims.outcome: Court held allegations sufficient; motion to dismiss denied as to this claim.

claims.claim: Violation of California Invasion of Privacy Act for recording confidential telephone communications without consent.
claims.legal_basis: California Penal Code § 632 (recording of confidential communications).
claims.outcome: Court held allegations sufficient; motion to dismiss denied as to this claim.

defenses.defense: ConverseNow did not unlawfully intercept communications and is not a third-party eavesdropper under CIPA.
defenses.legal_basis: Interpretation of California Penal Code §§ 631 and 632; argument that ConverseNow acted as an extension or tool of the restaurants rather than as a separate third party.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff failed to state a claim because the alleged communications were not confidential or protected under CIPA and/or consent was implied.
defenses.legal_basis: Pleading standards under Rule 12(b)(6) and statutory requirements of California Penal Code §§ 631 and 632 regarding confidentiality and consent.

case_id: 2022-07-28_USCOURTS-ilnd-1_20-cv-04699_In Re_ TikTok_ Inc._ Consumer Privacy Litigation.pdf
case_name: In re TikTok, Inc. Consumer Privacy Litigation
ai_relevance: TikTok’s AI and machine-learning recommendation and data-processing systems allegedly collected, analyzed, and shared users’ personal and biometric data without proper consent, creating the core privacy concerns underlying the settlement.
ai_presence: The summary explains that “The AI technology of TikTok, using machine learning to suggest content, is central to these privacy concerns.” It further notes that the key legal issue involves “data collection practices, including the use and sharing of personal and biometric information through its AI and ML systems.” These AI and ML systems are described as part of TikTok’s technology that recommends content and processes user data, which allegedly led to unlawful collection and handling of personal and biometric information.

parties.plaintiff_description: Class-action group of TikTok users alleging privacy violations
parties.defendant_description: Social media platform and its parent technology corporation

claims.claim: TikTok and ByteDance collected and mishandled users’ personal data, including biometric information, without informed consent.
claims.legal_basis: Federal and state privacy and consumer protection laws, including biometric privacy statutes and related data protection provisions (exact statutes vary by jurisdiction).
claims.outcome: Resolved by court-approved class settlement; defendants agreed to pay $92 million in monetary relief and accept injunctive obligations to change data practices.

claims.claim: TikTok and ByteDance unlawfully used and shared users’ personal and biometric information through their AI and machine-learning systems without adequate disclosure or authorization.
claims.legal_basis: State biometric information privacy laws and general privacy statutes prohibiting unauthorized collection, use, and disclosure of biometric and personal data.
claims.outcome: Resolved through the same $92 million settlement and injunctive relief; no adjudication on the merits, but practices are restricted and subject to new privacy protections.

claims.claim: TikTok’s data collection and sharing practices violated users’ reasonable expectations of privacy and constituted unfair or deceptive practices.
claims.legal_basis: State consumer protection and unfair or deceptive acts and practices (UDAP) laws, and related privacy protections.
claims.outcome: Claim settled on a class-wide basis; court found the settlement fair, reasonable, and adequate and granted final approval without a liability finding.

claims.claim: Class members are entitled to monetary compensation and prospective relief for past and future harms arising from TikTok’s alleged privacy violations.
claims.legal_basis: Class-action remedies under federal procedural rules and applicable state substantive privacy and consumer protection laws.
claims.outcome: Court certified a settlement class and subclass, approved $92 million in monetary relief, and ordered injunctive measures to prevent future violations.

claims.claim: Class counsel are entitled to attorneys’ fees and costs for obtaining relief for the class, and class representatives are entitled to service awards.
claims.legal_basis: Class action fee-shifting and common-fund doctrines under federal law and applicable rules governing attorneys’ fees and incentive awards in class settlements.
claims.outcome: Court approved distribution of attorneys’ fees and service awards as requested or as determined appropriate by the court in the final approval order.

defenses.defense: TikTok and ByteDance denied liability and wrongdoing while agreeing to settle the case.
defenses.legal_basis: General denial of alleged violations of federal and state privacy and consumer protection laws; settlement without admission of liability.

case_name: Frasco v. Flo Health, Inc.
ai_relevance: The dispute centers on Flo’s use of automated, SDK-based data collection and sharing systems that algorithmically transmitted users’ menstrual and pregnancy data to Meta and Google for analytics, tracking, and advertising-related purposes, raising questions about AI-driven data practices, consent, and privacy.
ai_presence: The summary describes that “AI and automated systems are central in how the Flo app reportedly used SDKs to share menstrual and pregnancy data with Meta and Google for commercial gain.” It explains that the Flo Period and Ovulation Tracker app integrated software development kits (SDKs) from Meta and Google, which automatically collected and transmitted sensitive health information (such as menstrual and pregnancy data) to those third parties. These automated, algorithmic tools were allegedly used for analytics, tracking, and monetization, forming the technological basis of the alleged privacy violations and informing the court’s analysis of common questions suitable for class-wide resolution.

parties.plaintiff_description: Putative nationwide and California privacy class
parties.defendant_description: App developer and large tech platforms

claims.claim: Privacy violations based on unlawful sharing of sensitive menstrual and pregnancy data with Meta and Google without valid consent.
claims.legal_basis: State and federal privacy laws and common-law privacy principles (including intrusion and related privacy tort theories).
claims.outcome: Certified to proceed on a class-wide basis for a nationwide class and a California subclass against Flo; related privacy claims against Meta and Google allowed to proceed under California law.

claims.claim: Breach of contract for violating Flo’s privacy commitments and assurances regarding how users’ health data would be collected, used, and shared.
claims.legal_basis: Contract law based on Flo’s Terms of Service and Privacy Policy promises regarding confidentiality and limits on data sharing.
claims.outcome: Certified for class treatment; the court held that common questions about whether Flo’s data-sharing practices breached uniform contractual commitments predominated and could be resolved for the class as a whole.

claims.claim: Invasion of privacy arising from the undisclosed transmission of intimate health information to third parties for commercial gain.
claims.legal_basis: Common-law invasion of privacy and California constitutional privacy rights for the California subclass.
claims.outcome: Certified for class treatment; the court found that whether Flo’s undisclosed sharing of reproductive health data with Meta and Google constituted a serious invasion of privacy is a common, class-wide question.

claims.claim: Violations of the California Invasion of Privacy Act (CIPA) based on alleged interception and disclosure of users’ communications and data through embedded SDKs.
claims.legal_basis: California Invasion of Privacy Act (CIPA), including provisions governing interception and disclosure of electronic communications.
claims.outcome: Class claims under CIPA against Meta and Google allowed to proceed for the California subclass; the court found that common issues regarding the SDK-based data collection and sharing predominated.

claims.claim: Invalidity of Flo’s class action waiver and related contractual limitations on users’ ability to bring class claims.
claims.legal_basis: Unconscionability doctrine under California contract law (procedural and substantive unconscionability of class action waiver and related terms).
claims.outcome: The court held the class action waiver in Flo’s terms of service unconscionable and unenforceable, allowing the case to proceed as a class action despite the waiver.

defenses.defense: Users gave implied or informed consent to data sharing with Meta and Google through acceptance of Flo’s Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.
defenses.legal_basis: Contract assent and consent principles; argument that continued use of the app and agreement to terms constituted informed consent to third-party data sharing.

defenses.defense: Flo’s contractual class action waiver and related arbitration/limitation provisions bar users from pursuing class-wide relief.
defenses.legal_basis: Enforcement of written contract terms under state contract law and federal policy favoring enforcement of arbitration and class action waivers.

defenses.defense: Data sharing was consistent with disclosed practices and therefore did not breach privacy commitments or constitute an invasion of privacy.
defenses.legal_basis: Contract interpretation and privacy law standards requiring a reasonable expectation of privacy and material nondisclosure for liability.

defenses.defense: For Meta and Google, any received data was obtained through standard SDK integrations and did not amount to unlawful interception or use under CIPA.
defenses.legal_basis: Statutory defenses and interpretations under the California Invasion of Privacy Act, including arguments about what constitutes interception, consent, and covered communications.

case_id: 2023-06-15_USCOURTS-ca7-22-02313_Citizens Insurance Company of America v. Wynndalco Enterprises_ LLC_ et al.pdf
case_name: Citizens Insurance Company of America v. Wynndalco Enterprises, LLC, et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute arises from Clearview AI’s facial-recognition system scraping and analyzing biometric data.
ai_presence: The case centers on alleged violations of Illinois’ Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) arising from the use of Clearview AI’s facial recognition software. Clearview AI collected, stored, and used individuals’ biometric identifiers (faceprints) by scraping photographs from the internet and applying facial-recognition algorithms. Wynndalco Enterprises allegedly facilitated the deployment or distribution of Clearview AI’s facial-recognition technology, which enabled identification of individuals from images without their consent. The insurance-coverage dispute turns on whether Citizens Insurance must defend Wynndalco against lawsuits premised on this AI-driven biometric data collection and analysis.

parties.plaintiff_description: Insurance company seeking coverage determination
parties.defendant_description: Business insured under policy; alleged BIPA violator

claims.claim: Declaratory judgment that Citizens has no duty to defend or indemnify Wynndalco for underlying lawsuits alleging BIPA violations and related common-law privacy claims.
claims.legal_basis: Insurance contract interpretation; application of policy’s “violation-of-statutes” exclusion and catch-all provision under Illinois law.
claims.outcome: Rejected. Seventh Circuit held the catch-all exclusion is ambiguous and construed it in favor of coverage; Citizens has a duty to defend Wynndalco against the BIPA and related claims.

claims.claim: Underlying claim (against Wynndalco): Violations of Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) based on collection, use, and dissemination of biometric identifiers via Clearview AI’s facial-recognition technology without informed consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, including provisions governing collection, storage, use, and disclosure of biometric identifiers and biometric information.
claims.outcome: Not decided in this appeal. The Seventh Circuit addressed only insurance coverage and held that Citizens must defend Wynndalco against these BIPA claims; merits remain for underlying courts.

claims.claim: Underlying claim (against Wynndalco): Common-law privacy and related tort claims arising from unauthorized capture and use of individuals’ facial biometric data through Clearview AI’s system.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois common-law privacy torts (such as intrusion upon seclusion, appropriation of likeness, or similar privacy-based causes of action).
claims.outcome: Not decided in this appeal. The Seventh Circuit held Citizens must defend Wynndalco against these related common-law claims; liability on the merits remains unresolved in the underlying actions.

defenses.defense: Policy’s “violation-of-statutes” exclusion bars coverage for BIPA claims because BIPA is a statute that regulates the collection and use of personal or biometric information, falling within the exclusion’s catch-all language.
defenses.legal_basis: Insurance policy exclusion for violations of statutes that govern or restrict the sending, transmitting, communicating, or distribution of information; contract interpretation under Illinois law.

defenses.defense: Because the exclusion applies, Citizens has no duty to defend or indemnify Wynndalco in the underlying BIPA and related privacy lawsuits.
defenses.legal_basis: Illinois insurance law principles that an unambiguous exclusion precludes coverage and thus eliminates the duty to defend.

case_id: 2023-07-11_USCOURTS-ca7-20-03134_Matt Dinerstein v. Google_ LLC_ et al.pdf
case_name: Matt Dinerstein v. Google LLC, et al.
ai_relevance: Research collaboration used AI-driven software to predict healthcare needs from anonymized patient data, prompting privacy and contract claims.
ai_presence: The case involves “a research collaboration between Google and the University of Chicago to develop software using AI to predict healthcare needs using anonymized patient data.” The opinion discusses Google’s work with the University of Chicago Medical Center to create predictive tools based on patient records, where artificial intelligence and related algorithms are applied to de-identified medical information to forecast future healthcare needs.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual patient and putative class representative
parties.defendant_description: Technology company and university medical provider

claims.claim: Improper disclosure and misuse of medical records in research collaboration with Google
claims.legal_basis: Article III standing premised on alleged privacy invasion and loss of control over personal data; underlying theories included common-law privacy and related harms
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of Article III standing; alleged privacy harms deemed speculative and not concrete or imminent

claims.claim: Breach of contract based on hospital’s patient agreements regarding confidentiality of medical information
claims.legal_basis: State-law breach of contract, alleging the University of Chicago promised to keep medical records confidential and not share identifiable data with third parties like Google
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of Article III standing; no concrete contractual injury or actual misuse of data sufficiently alleged

claims.claim: Consumer fraud and deceptive practices related to representations about confidentiality of medical information
claims.legal_basis: State consumer-fraud statute (consumer protection law) based on allegedly misleading assurances about privacy and data handling
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of Article III standing; alleged economic and informational injuries were too speculative and not plausibly tied to the data transfer

claims.claim: Invasion of privacy through disclosure of anonymized but allegedly re-identifiable medical data to Google
claims.legal_basis: Common-law privacy/intrusion and disclosure theories, framed as loss of privacy and risk of re-identification
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of Article III standing; court found no concrete injury, only conjectural risk of re-identification

claims.claim: Unjust enrichment arising from Google’s and the University’s use of his medical data without adequate compensation or consent
claims.legal_basis: State-law unjust enrichment, premised on alleged improper benefit from use of his medical information in AI research
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of Article III standing; no concrete loss or cognizable benefit taken from plaintiff personally was adequately alleged

defenses.defense: Plaintiff lacks Article III standing because he failed to allege a concrete, particularized, and actual or imminent injury from the data transfer
defenses.legal_basis: U.S. Constitution Article III standing requirements; Spokeo and related precedent on concreteness of injury

defenses.defense: Alleged privacy harms are speculative, based on hypothetical re-identification and future misuse of data
defenses.legal_basis: Article III injury-in-fact doctrine requiring non-speculative, imminent harm

defenses.defense: No economic or contractual injury because plaintiff did not plausibly allege overpayment, loss of benefit of the bargain, or diminution in value of his data
defenses.legal_basis: Article III standing for economic injury; state contract principles on benefit of the bargain

defenses.defense: Consumer-fraud and deceptive-practices claims fail for lack of a concrete, causally connected injury
defenses.legal_basis: Article III standing plus state consumer-protection statutes’ injury requirements

defenses.defense: Use of de-identified/anonymized medical data in research collaboration complied with applicable privacy standards and did not create a legally cognizable invasion of privacy
defenses.legal_basis: Health privacy law framework (including de-identification concepts under HIPAA) and common-law privacy doctrines requiring disclosure of identifiable information

case_id: 2025-03-06_USCOURTS-ilsd-3_23-cv-01321_Moomaw et al v. Geosnapshot Pty Ltd et al.pdf
case_name: Moomaw et al v. GeoSnapShot Pty Ltd et al
ai_relevance: Defendant’s AI-driven photo platform used facial recognition to extract biometric identifiers from event photos of Illinois residents, enabling photo search and sale and forming the basis of alleged BIPA violations and personal-jurisdiction contacts.
ai_presence: The summary describes GeoSnap’s “AI-driven photo platform, which facilitated the extraction of facial biometrics from photos” and notes “the use of facial recognition AI” on its online platform to identify individuals in event photos and conduct commerce with Illinois residents.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individuals alleging biometric privacy violations
parties.defendant_description: Australian company running AI photo platform

claims.claim: Violation of the Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) by collecting and using facial geometry biometrics from Illinois residents without informed consent, notice, or required disclosures.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/1 et seq.
claims.outcome: Not resolved on the merits at this stage; court denied GeoSnap’s motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction, allowing the BIPA claims to proceed in Illinois.

defenses.defense: The Illinois federal court lacks personal jurisdiction over GeoSnap, an Australian company, for plaintiffs’ BIPA claims.
defenses.legal_basis: Constitutional due process limits on specific personal jurisdiction; minimum contacts and purposeful-availment standards under U.S. Supreme Court precedent.

case_id: 2025-03-20_USCOURTS-ilsd-3_23-cv-01321_Moomaw et al v. Geosnapshot Pty Ltd et al.pdf
case_name: Moomaw et al. v. GeoSnapShot Pty Ltd et al.
ai_relevance: GeoSnapShot allegedly used AI-powered facial matching to identify event participants in photos and sell images, leading to biometric privacy claims under BIPA.
ai_presence: The summary states that GeoSnapShot "uses AI to match event participants' photos for sale" and that the case concerns "the collection and use of their biometric data without proper consent" in connection with this AI-based photo-matching system.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual consumers and putative BIPA class members
parties.defendant_description: Company providing AI photo-matching event photography services

claims.claim: Violation of the Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) by collecting, storing, and using plaintiffs’ biometric identifiers and information from event photographs without informed written consent, without proper disclosures, and without a compliant retention and destruction policy.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/1 et seq.
claims.outcome: Claim survives at this stage; court denied GeoSnapShot’s motion to dismiss based on arbitration and contract formation arguments, allowing the BIPA class-action claim to proceed.

claims.claim: Class-action claim on behalf of similarly situated Illinois residents whose biometric data was allegedly captured and used by GeoSnapShot through its AI photo-matching system without BIPA-compliant consent and disclosures.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act class-action provisions and Illinois class action procedural rules (e.g., Fed. R. Civ. P. 23 for federal class certification).
claims.outcome: Class claims not dismissed; court’s denial of motion to compel arbitration and to dismiss allows putative class claims to continue in this court.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs’ claims must be arbitrated because they agreed to arbitration clauses in Tough Mudder liability waivers, and GeoSnapShot, as a third-party beneficiary or closely related entity, can enforce those arbitration provisions.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Arbitration Act and state contract law principles on enforcing arbitration agreements, including third-party beneficiary and equitable estoppel doctrines.
defenses.defense_outcome: Rejected. Court held GeoSnapShot, a non-signatory, could not compel arbitration because the clauses did not clearly confer a direct benefit or show intent to benefit non-signatories like GeoSnapShot.

defenses.defense: Complaint should be dismissed because the Tough Mudder agreements, including liability waivers and terms, bar or limit plaintiffs’ claims and require resolution outside this court.
defenses.legal_basis: Contract law defenses based on waiver, release, and forum/arbitration selection clauses in Tough Mudder participation agreements.
defenses.defense_outcome: Rejected. Court denied the motion to dismiss, finding contract formation and scope issues and insufficient evidence that plaintiffs agreed to terms benefiting GeoSnapShot.

case_id: 2024-03-07_USCOURTS-ilsd-3_23-cv-01321_Moomaw et al v. Geosnapshot Pty Ltd et al.pdf
case_name: Moomaw et al. v. GeoSnapShot Pty Ltd et al.
ai_relevance: GeoSnapShot’s platform used AI-based facial recognition-style matching: users uploaded a selfie, the system extracted facial geometry, and automatically compared it to event photos to locate images of the user, allegedly collecting and processing biometric identifiers in violation of BIPA.
ai_presence: "GeoSnapShot's platform used AI to allow users to search for photographs taken at events by uploading a 'selfie,' thereby extracting and comparing facial geometry data from the images."

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual Illinois residents, class representatives
parties.defendant_description: Foreign and U.S. corporations operating photo platform

claims.claim: Violation of the Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) by collecting, using, and storing facial biometric data from Illinois residents without complying with statutory requirements.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/1 et seq.
claims.outcome: Substantive BIPA claims not resolved at this stage; court addressed only personal jurisdiction and allowed the case to proceed against GeoSnapShot Pty Ltd in Illinois, with jurisdictional discovery ordered as to GeoSnapShot, Inc.

claims.claim: Class-action claims on behalf of similarly situated individuals whose facial biometrics were collected via GeoSnapShot’s platform at Illinois events.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23 and BIPA, 740 ILCS 14/1 et seq.
claims.outcome: Class certification not yet decided; case allowed to proceed past motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction as to GeoSnapShot Pty Ltd, with jurisdictional discovery regarding GeoSnapShot, Inc.

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction over GeoSnapShot Pty Ltd in Illinois courts.
defenses.legal_basis: Due Process Clause; minimum contacts and specific jurisdiction standards under International Shoe and its progeny.
defenses.defense_outcome: Rejected. Court found sufficient minimum contacts and denied GeoSnapShot Pty Ltd’s motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction.

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction over GeoSnapShot, Inc. due to insufficient contacts with Illinois.
defenses.legal_basis: Due Process Clause; minimum contacts and specific jurisdiction standards under International Shoe and its progeny.
defenses.defense_outcome: Partially credited for now. Court did not dismiss but ordered limited jurisdictional discovery to determine whether personal jurisdiction over GeoSnapShot, Inc. exists.

case_name: Tate v. VITAS Healthcare Corporation (re Invoca conversation intelligence software)
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on Invoca’s AI-powered conversation intelligence software recording and analyzing calls without consent under CIPA.
ai_presence: The case involves Invoca’s “AI-powered conversation intelligence software,” which “records, analyzes, and stores call data without the consent of the callers.” The software is described as “conversation intelligence software” used by VITAS and provided by Invoca, capable of “recording and analyzing phone calls” and using “data collected from VITAS’s calls for its own purposes.” The court’s analysis turns on whether Invoca, through this automated, AI-driven system that processes call content, acts as a third party under the California Invasion of Privacy Act by “recording and analyzing phone calls without the consent of all parties.”

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual consumer and caller alleging privacy violations
parties.defendant_description: Healthcare company and software provider using call analytics

claims.claim: Unlawful wiretapping and eavesdropping on telephone calls through use of Invoca’s conversation intelligence software without consent of all parties.
claims.legal_basis: California Invasion of Privacy Act (CIPA), including section 631(a) (interception by a third party).
claims.outcome: Court denied VITAS Healthcare Corporation’s motion to dismiss; claim under CIPA § 631(a) may proceed against VITAS and Invoca because Invoca can be treated as a third party capable of using call data for its own purposes.

claims.claim: Aiding and abetting unlawful interception and recording of calls by Invoca’s system.
claims.legal_basis: California Invasion of Privacy Act (CIPA) aiding-and-abetting liability principles under section 631(a).
claims.outcome: Court held that, because Invoca may be a third party and can use the data for its own purposes, both VITAS and Invoca may face aiding-and-abetting liability; motion to dismiss on this theory was denied, allowing the aiding-and-abetting claim to proceed.

defenses.defense: Invoca is merely a tool or extension of VITAS, not a separate third party, so CIPA § 631(a) does not apply.
defenses.legal_basis: Interpretation of “third party” under California Invasion of Privacy Act § 631(a), arguing vendor-as-agent exception and lack of independent use of data.

defenses.defense: No actionable interception or unlawful recording occurred because callers implicitly consented to any monitoring or recording associated with customer service operations.
defenses.legal_basis: Consent defense under California Invasion of Privacy Act, relying on implied consent doctrine and customary business practices in recorded customer service calls.

case_name: Dzananovic v. Bumble Inc. et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on Bumble’s automated facial recognition system used in photo verification, allegedly collecting and processing biometric identifiers without informed consent under BIPA.
ai_presence: The case describes Bumble’s dating app as using a “photo verification” feature that relies on facial recognition technology. This automated system analyzes users’ facial geometry from uploaded photos or live images to verify identity. The plaintiff alleges that this facial recognition process collects, captures, and stores biometric identifiers and biometric information without providing required disclosures or obtaining written consent, in violation of Illinois’s Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA). The court’s summary notes that the app’s facial recognition technology is at the core of the alleged statutory violations and is the technological basis for the claimed biometric data collection in Illinois.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual Illinois user of Bumble app
parties.defendant_description: Corporate operators of Bumble dating application

claims.claim: Violation of Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) § 15(b) for collecting or capturing biometric identifiers/biometric information via facial recognition without informed written consent and required disclosures.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(b).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied as to personal jurisdiction; BIPA § 15(b) claim allowed to proceed at this stage.

claims.claim: Violation of Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) § 15(a) for failing to develop, publicly disclose, and comply with a written policy for retention and destruction of biometric identifiers/biometric information collected through the photo verification feature.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(a).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied as to personal jurisdiction; BIPA § 15(a) claim allowed to proceed at this stage.

claims.claim: Class action claims on behalf of similarly situated Illinois users whose biometric data was allegedly collected and processed through Bumble’s facial recognition-based photo verification without BIPA-compliant notice, consent, and policies.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/1 et seq.; Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23 (class action mechanism).
claims.outcome: Court denied defendants’ motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction, allowing the putative class BIPA claims to move forward; class certification not yet decided.

defenses.defense: The court lacks personal jurisdiction over Bumble, Inc. and related entities because their contacts with Illinois are insufficient and any alleged BIPA violations do not arise out of Illinois-directed conduct.
defenses.legal_basis: Constitutional due process limits on specific personal jurisdiction under the Fourteenth Amendment; Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(2).

defenses.defense: Bumble’s marketing and app operations are nationally oriented and not purposefully directed at Illinois in a way that would justify specific jurisdiction for BIPA claims.
defenses.legal_basis: Specific personal jurisdiction doctrine requiring purposeful availment and claims arising out of forum-related conduct under U.S. Supreme Court and Seventh Circuit precedent.

case_id: 2022-01-27_USCOURTS-ilnd-1_21-cv-00135_In Re_ Clearview AI_ Inc._ Consumer Privacy Litigation.pdf
case_name: In re Clearview AI, Inc. Consumer Privacy Litigation (Macy’s Retail Holdings, LLC)
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on Macy’s alleged use of Clearview AI’s facial recognition database to identify individuals from surveillance footage without consent, implicating AI-based biometric identification and data-scraping technology.
ai_presence: The case summary describes that Macy’s allegedly used “AI technology to identify individuals from surveillance footage by accessing the Clearview AI database, which contains biometric data harvested from images scraped from the internet.” The database is described as containing “biometric data harvested from images scraped from the internet,” and Macy’s is alleged to have “used this database without consent.” The court characterizes this as Macy’s “unauthorized use” of the Clearview AI system, which is an AI-powered facial recognition and biometric identification tool, to collect and profit from individuals’ biometric information without consent.

parties.plaintiff_description: Class-action group of affected consumers
parties.defendant_description: Retail corporation alleged Clearview AI user

claims.claim: Violation of the Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) by collecting, using, and profiting from plaintiffs’ biometric identifiers and information via the Clearview AI facial recognition database without informed written consent, required disclosures, or a publicly available retention and destruction policy.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/1 et seq.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied as to BIPA claims; court held plaintiffs sufficiently alleged concrete injury and statutory violations, so BIPA claims may proceed.

claims.claim: Violation of California consumer protection and privacy laws, including claims that Macy’s unfairly and unlawfully used Clearview AI’s facial recognition database to obtain and exploit Californians’ biometric information without notice or consent.
claims.legal_basis: California Unfair Competition Law (UCL), Cal. Bus. & Prof. Code § 17200 et seq., and related California statutory privacy/consumer protection provisions as pleaded in the complaint.
claims.outcome: Some California UCL and related state-law claims were dismissed on Macy’s motion to dismiss; others (not specified in the summary) were allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Violation of New York state law based on Macy’s alleged collection and use of New Yorkers’ biometric data through Clearview AI without consent, including a claim for unjust enrichment.
claims.legal_basis: New York common law, including unjust enrichment, and any New York statutory privacy or consumer protection provisions asserted in the complaint.
claims.outcome: The unjust enrichment claim under New York common law was dismissed on Macy’s motion to dismiss; other New York-based claims not specifically identified in the summary may proceed if not dismissed.

claims.claim: General invasion of privacy and misuse of biometric identifiers by using Clearview AI’s facial recognition technology to identify individuals from surveillance footage without their knowledge or consent, and to profit from that data.
claims.legal_basis: State privacy and consumer protection laws of Illinois, California, New York, and potentially other states as incorporated in the multi-state class action, including BIPA and analogous doctrines.
claims.outcome: To the extent these theories are embodied in BIPA and surviving state-law claims, they were allowed to proceed; where framed as California UCL or New York unjust enrichment, some were dismissed as described above.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs lack standing because alleged injuries from Macy’s use of Clearview AI’s database are not concrete or particularized.
defenses.legal_basis: Article III standing requirements under the U.S. Constitution and related federal justiciability doctrines.

defenses.defense: Complaints fail to state a claim under BIPA and other state laws because Macy’s did not itself collect or control biometric data in a manner covered by the statutes, or because statutory elements (such as notice, consent, or profit) were not adequately pleaded.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); statutory interpretation of BIPA and analogous state laws.

defenses.defense: California Unfair Competition Law and certain New York common-law claims (including unjust enrichment) are not legally viable on the facts alleged, either because plaintiffs lack statutory standing, have adequate remedies at law, or have not alleged the required elements such as unlawful, unfair, or fraudulent conduct or independent enrichment.
defenses.legal_basis: California Unfair Competition Law (Cal. Bus. & Prof. Code § 17200 et seq.); New York common law of unjust enrichment; Rule 12(b)(6).

case_id: 2022-03-30_USCOURTS-ilnd-1_20-cv-03873_Citizens Insurance Company Of America v. Wynndalco Enterprises_ LLC et al.pdf
case_name: Citizens Insurance Company of America v. Wynndalco Enterprises, LLC et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute arises from sale of access to Clearview AI’s facial recognition database, an AI-based biometric identification system.
ai_presence: The summary states that the underlying class actions alleged “violations of the Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) due to the sale of access to an AI-based facial recognition database created by Clearview AI.” It further explains that Wynndalco allegedly sold access to this AI-based facial recognition database, which used biometric information (faceprints) to identify individuals. The insurance coverage dispute centers on whether Citizens must defend Wynndalco against these lawsuits arising from its involvement with Clearview AI’s facial recognition technology.

parties.plaintiff_description: Insurance company seeking declaratory judgment on coverage obligations
parties.defendant_description: Business insured under policy; sued in BIPA class actions

claims.claim: Request for declaratory judgment that Citizens has no duty to defend Wynndalco in two underlying BIPA class-action lawsuits.
claims.legal_basis: Interpretation of commercial general liability insurance policy, including statutory violation exclusion and Illinois contract/insurance law principles.
claims.outcome: Rejected. Court held the statutory violation exclusion is ambiguous as applied to BIPA, construed ambiguity in favor of insured, and ruled Citizens must defend Wynndalco in the underlying lawsuits.

claims.claim: Request for declaratory judgment that Citizens has no duty to indemnify Wynndalco for any liability arising from the underlying BIPA class actions.
claims.legal_basis: Same insurance policy interpretation, focusing on coverage grants, exclusions, and Illinois law on indemnity obligations.
claims.outcome: Not definitively resolved on the merits in the provided summary; court’s ruling focused on duty to defend, leaving indemnity to be determined based on future developments in the underlying suits and policy interpretation.

defenses.defense: The statutory violation exclusion in the policy bars coverage for BIPA claims, so Citizens owes no duty to defend or indemnify.
defenses.legal_basis: Policy’s statutory violation exclusion language and Illinois law enforcing clear and unambiguous insurance contract terms.

defenses.defense: BIPA violations do not fall within the policy’s covered “personal and advertising injury,” so there is no initial grant of coverage.
defenses.legal_basis: Construction of the policy’s insuring agreement defining “personal and advertising injury” under Illinois insurance contract interpretation principles.

case_id: 2025-01-17_USCOURTS-ilsd-3_22-cv-00046_Lewis v. Maverick Transportation LLC et al.pdf
case_name: Lewis v. Maverick Transportation LLC et al.
ai_relevance: Case centers on Lytx’s machine vision and artificial intelligence system (DriveCam) used to monitor drivers and predict distracted driving, allegedly collecting and storing biometric data without consent in violation of Illinois BIPA.
ai_presence: The case summary states the dispute involves “the use of machine vision and artificial intelligence (MV+AI) to predict distracted driving behaviors using Lytx’s DriveCam.” It further explains that plaintiffs allege privacy violations under the Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) arising from this MV+AI technology, which purportedly collected and stored biometric data from vehicle operators without their consent.

parties.plaintiff_description: Drivers and class representatives under BIPA
parties.defendant_description: Company providing DriveCam MV+AI monitoring system

claims.claim: Violation of the Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) by collecting, capturing, and using drivers’ biometric identifiers and/or biometric information through Lytx’s DriveCam MV+AI system without informed written consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/1 et seq.
claims.outcome: Resolved by proposed class action settlement; court granted preliminary approval, finding the $4.25 million non-reversionary settlement fund likely fair, reasonable, and adequate, with final approval to be decided after a fairness hearing.

claims.claim: Failure to provide required written disclosures and retention schedule regarding collection, storage, and use of biometric data obtained via the MV+AI DriveCam system.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act disclosure and retention provisions, 740 ILCS 14/15(a)–(b).
claims.outcome: Included within the class action settlement; court preliminarily approved settlement as likely fair, with no separate adjudication on the merits.

claims.claim: Unlawful storage and dissemination risk of biometric data collected through the MV+AI DriveCam system without complying with BIPA’s safeguards and consent requirements.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, including safeguards and consent provisions, 740 ILCS 14/15(a)–(e).
claims.outcome: Addressed and released as part of the preliminarily approved class settlement; no merits ruling on liability.

defenses.defense: Settlement without admission of liability; defendants deny violating BIPA or any laws but agree to settle to avoid the burden, expense, and uncertainty of continued litigation.
defenses.legal_basis: General civil settlement principles; Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23 governing class action settlements.

case_id: 2024-06-27_USCOURTS-cand-5_23-cv-05096_Tibbs et al v. Arlo Technologies_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Tibbs et al. v. Arlo Technologies, Inc.
ai_relevance: Claims center on Arlo security systems’ AI-powered facial recognition and biometric analytics that capture, process, and store delivery drivers’ biometric identifiers without BIPA-compliant notice, consent, or retention policies.
ai_presence: The summary describes Arlo’s “home security systems” as using “facial recognition and other AI-powered features to capture biometric data.” The alleged BIPA violations arise from these AI-driven capabilities that automatically detect, capture, and store biometric information (such as facial geometry) of delivery drivers without informed consent and without a publicly available data retention and destruction policy.

parties.plaintiff_description: Putative class of Illinois delivery drivers
parties.defendant_description: Technology company providing home security systems

claims.claim: Class action claim seeking statutory damages, injunctive relief, and other remedies for Arlo’s alleged systemic BIPA violations affecting a class of Illinois delivery drivers.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act private right of action, 740 ILCS 14/20, and Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23 (class action).
claims.outcome: Court found plaintiffs adequately alleged Article III standing and viable BIPA claims; motion to dismiss denied, allowing class claims to move forward at the pleading stage.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs lack Article III standing because they did not suffer a concrete injury from the alleged biometric data practices.
defenses.legal_basis: Article III of the U.S. Constitution; standing jurisprudence including Spokeo and related federal cases on intangible harms.

defenses.defense: Arlo’s conduct is not subject to BIPA or falls within statutory limitations or exceptions, so the statute does not apply to its security systems as used here.
defenses.legal_basis: Interpretation and scope of Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, including statutory definitions and exemptions.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs failed to state a claim under BIPA because their allegations about collection, consent, disclosure, and retention policies are insufficiently pled or conclusory.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) (failure to state a claim).

defenses.defense: Motion to strike plaintiffs’ supplemental authority submitted in support of their opposition to dismissal, arguing it was improper or irrelevant.
defenses.legal_basis: Court’s inherent authority and Federal Rules of Civil Procedure governing motions practice and supplemental filings.

case_id: 2022-02-14_USCOURTS-ilnd-1_21-cv-00135_In Re_ Clearview AI_ Inc._ Consumer Privacy Litigation.pdf
case_name: In re Clearview AI, Inc. Consumer Privacy Litigation
ai_relevance: Defendants allegedly used AI-based facial recognition algorithms to scrape, analyze, and create a searchable database of biometric identifiers from online images without consent, then sold access to that AI-powered system to third parties, forming the core privacy and BIPA issues in the case.
ai_presence: The case centers on Clearview AI’s use of artificial intelligence algorithms to scrape photographs from the internet, scan and analyze individuals’ facial geometry, and create a massive facial recognition database. Plaintiffs allege that Clearview AI used “very smart computer algorithms” and “artificial intelligence” to collect, analyze, and match biometric identifiers (faceprints) from images posted online, then offered an AI-powered facial recognition tool that allows users to upload a photo and identify the person by searching Clearview’s database. The court’s summary describes Clearview’s technology as using AI to collect and analyze biometric data without consent, and emphasizes the alleged misuse of biometric data obtained through AI technology as the basis for the BIPA and related privacy claims.

parties.plaintiff_description: Putative class of individuals alleging biometric privacy violations
parties.defendant_description: Technology company and related defendants offering facial recognition services

claims.claim: Violation of Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) for unlawful collection, capture, and storage of biometric identifiers and information without informed written consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/1 et seq.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; court held plaintiffs adequately alleged BIPA violations and allowed these claims to proceed.

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA for failure to provide and publish a written, publicly available retention schedule and guidelines for permanently destroying biometric identifiers and information.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(a).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; claim sufficiently pled and allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA for unlawful disclosure, dissemination, and sale of biometric identifiers and information to third parties without consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(d).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; court found allegations sufficient to move forward.

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA for profiting from biometric identifiers and information without consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/15(c).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; claim allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Invasion of privacy / intrusion upon seclusion based on surreptitious scraping, analysis, and commercial exploitation of facial biometric data.
claims.legal_basis: Common law invasion of privacy / intrusion upon seclusion under various state laws.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; court held plaintiffs plausibly alleged intrusion upon seclusion claims.

claims.claim: Violation of other state privacy and consumer protection statutes arising from unauthorized collection and use of biometric and personal data.
claims.legal_basis: Various state privacy and consumer protection laws (non-Illinois) pleaded in the multi-state class action.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss largely denied; most statutory privacy and consumer protection claims allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Unjust enrichment under New York law based on Clearview’s alleged wrongful profits from individuals’ biometric data.
claims.legal_basis: New York common law unjust enrichment.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss granted; court held the New York unjust enrichment claim was preempted or otherwise barred and dismissed that claim.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs failed to state a claim because Clearview’s conduct does not fall within the scope of BIPA or comparable privacy statutes.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); statutory interpretation of BIPA and other state laws.

defenses.defense: Certain state-law claims, including New York unjust enrichment, are preempted or displaced by existing statutory schemes and therefore cannot proceed.
defenses.legal_basis: Preemption and displacement doctrines under New York and other applicable state laws.

defenses.defense: Use of publicly available photographs from the internet and creation of a searchable database is protected or otherwise not actionable under privacy laws.
defenses.legal_basis: Arguments grounded in privacy and free-speech principles and limitations on statutory reach (exact constitutional bases not detailed in the summary).

case_name: Jones v. Peloton Interactive, Inc.
ai_relevance: Plaintiff alleges Peloton’s Drift-powered website chat intercepted messages to improve Drift’s AI technologies, making AI-based data processing central to the privacy dispute.
ai_presence: The summary states that Peloton’s website chat feature used embedded software from Drift, which allegedly intercepted and recorded user communications without consent "to enhance Drift's AI technologies." The court found sufficient allegations that Drift acted as a third-party eavesdropper for its own purposes, including using the intercepted chat data to improve its AI systems.

parties.plaintiff_description: Website user bringing CIPA class action claims
parties.defendant_description: Corporation operating Peloton’s website and chat feature

claims.claim: Violation of the California Invasion of Privacy Act (CIPA) Section 631(a) based on interception and recording of website chat communications through Drift’s embedded software without users’ consent, and use of those communications for Drift’s own purposes, including improving its AI technologies.
claims.legal_basis: California Invasion of Privacy Act, Cal. Penal Code § 631(a) (wiretapping/eavesdropping on communications without consent, including by a third-party eavesdropper).
claims.outcome: On Peloton’s motion to dismiss, the court held plaintiff plausibly alleged a Section 631(a) claim by sufficiently pleading that Drift acted as a third-party eavesdropper intercepting communications for its own benefit; the motion to dismiss was denied and the claim proceeds.

defenses.defense: Drift was merely Peloton’s vendor/agent assisting with chat services, not a third-party eavesdropper, so there was no unlawful interception under CIPA Section 631(a).
defenses.legal_basis: Interpretation of Cal. Penal Code § 631(a) limiting liability where a service provider acts as an extension or agent of the party to the communication rather than as an independent third-party eavesdropper.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff failed to state a plausible claim under CIPA because the alleged conduct does not meet the statutory elements of unlawful interception or eavesdropping.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) (failure to state a claim) and statutory elements of Cal. Penal Code § 631(a).

case_id: 2016-04-06_USCOURTS-moed-4_15-md-02669_IN RE_ ASHLEY MADISON CUSTOMER DATA SECURITY BREACH LITIGATION.pdf
case_name: In re Ashley Madison Customer Data Security Breach Litigation
ai_relevance: Defendant allegedly used automated ‘bots’ to mimic real users on the Ashley Madison website, deceiving customers about interactions and relationships available on the platform.
ai_presence: The summary states that plaintiffs "claim Avid inadequately secured data and used AI bots to mimic users" on the Ashley Madison website, meaning automated software agents were deployed to pose as real users and interact with customers.

parties.plaintiff_description: Putative class of website users, data-breach victims
parties.defendant_description: Operator of Ashley Madison online dating website

claims.claim: Avid failed to adequately secure and protect users’ personal and financial information, leading to a data breach exposing that information.
claims.legal_basis: Negligence / data security obligations and related privacy protections under applicable law (exact statutes not specified in summary).
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this order; the court addressed only whether named plaintiffs may proceed under pseudonyms as class representatives.

claims.claim: Avid used AI bots to mimic real users on the Ashley Madison website, misleading customers about the authenticity of other users and interactions.
claims.legal_basis: Consumer protection and fraud/misrepresentation theories (exact statutory bases not specified in summary).
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this order; the court’s ruling was limited to anonymity of class representatives.

claims.claim: Plaintiffs sought permission for named plaintiffs to proceed under pseudonyms while serving as class representatives in the class action.
claims.legal_basis: Procedural law governing anonymity in litigation and class actions; balancing privacy interests against public access and class-member accountability.
claims.outcome: Court denied the motion: plaintiffs may not serve as class representatives under pseudonyms; if they wish to be class representatives, they must reveal their real names.

claims.claim: Plaintiffs sought to proceed anonymously as individual class members (without serving as class representatives) to avoid exposure and potential harm from public disclosure of their Ashley Madison use.
claims.legal_basis: Same procedural anonymity principles, applied to non-representative class members and privacy interests in sensitive personal information.
claims.outcome: Court allowed anonymity for plaintiffs who choose not to be class representatives; they may remain pseudonymous as ordinary class members.

defenses.defense: Class representatives must be publicly identified so that absent class members and the court can ensure accountability, adequacy of representation, and avoid conflicts of interest.
defenses.legal_basis: Class action procedural requirements and principles of transparency and open judicial proceedings under Federal Rules of Civil Procedure and public access doctrines.

defenses.defense: The public’s and class members’ interest in knowing who represents the class outweighs the named plaintiffs’ interest in anonymity when they seek to act as class representatives.
defenses.legal_basis: Balancing test applied in pseudonym cases under federal procedural and constitutional open-courts principles.

case_id: 2022-03-23_USCOURTS-ilnd-1_21-cv-00135_In Re_ Clearview AI_ Inc._ Consumer Privacy Litigation.pdf
case_name: In re Clearview AI, Inc. Consumer Privacy Litigation
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on Clearview AI’s facial recognition system built from scraped online images, allegedly violating privacy and free speech rights.
ai_presence: The case concerns Clearview AI, Inc.’s facial recognition database, which is created using a “fancy computer program that recognizes faces in photos” by scraping images from the internet without consent. Plaintiffs allege that Clearview’s use of this facial recognition technology and database violates privacy and free speech rights under the California Constitution, and that various municipal defendants used Clearview’s AI-powered facial recognition system in ways that infringed those rights.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individuals/class alleging privacy and speech violations
parties.defendant_description: AI company and municipal government defendants

claims.claim: Use of Clearview’s facial recognition database created from scraped online images without consent violated plaintiffs’ privacy rights under the California Constitution.
claims.legal_basis: California Constitution right to privacy; state constitutional privacy protections; related state privacy law principles.
claims.outcome: Court did not reach the merits; held there was a reasonable possibility plaintiffs could succeed against municipal defendants and therefore remanded the case to state court under 28 U.S.C. § 1447(e).

claims.claim: Use of Clearview’s facial recognition technology and database violated plaintiffs’ free speech rights under the California Constitution.
claims.legal_basis: California Constitution free speech protections; state constitutional law on expressive and associational rights.
claims.outcome: Court did not adjudicate the free speech claim’s merits; found the claim at least potentially viable against municipal defendants, supporting the conclusion that joinder was not fraudulent and remand to state court was required.

claims.claim: Claims against nondiverse municipal defendants (for their use of Clearview’s facial recognition system) are properly joined and not fraudulent, so the case should be remanded to state court.
claims.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1447(e); fraudulent joinder doctrine; rules governing joinder of parties and subject-matter jurisdiction based on diversity.
claims.outcome: Court agreed with plaintiffs, held that municipal defendants were not fraudulently joined, found a reasonable possibility of success on claims against them, and granted plaintiffs’ motion to remand the case to state court.

defenses.defense: Municipal defendants were fraudulently joined solely to defeat diversity jurisdiction and keep the case out of federal court.
defenses.legal_basis: Fraudulent joinder doctrine under federal diversity jurisdiction principles; 28 U.S.C. §§ 1332, 1441, 1447.
defenses.defense_outcome: Rejected. The court held plaintiffs had a reasonable possibility of succeeding on claims against municipal defendants, so joinder was not fraudulent.

defenses.defense: Claims against municipal defendants should be severed from the claims against Clearview AI so that the federal court could retain jurisdiction over the diverse parties.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal procedural rules on severance and misjoinder (e.g., Fed. R. Civ. P. 20, 21) and discretionary authority under 28 U.S.C. § 1447(e).
defenses.defense_outcome: Rejected. The court denied the request to sever, concluding that severance was not appropriate and that remand of the entire action to state court was warranted.

case_name: Naughton v. Amazon.com, Inc. et al.
ai_relevance: Case centers on Amazon’s alleged use of facial recognition and biometric scanning systems to collect employees’ facial geometry during wellness checks without consent, policies, or disclosures.
ai_presence: The summary explains that AI and associated technologies are central to the case, as Amazon allegedly used facial recognition systems to collect biometric data, including facial geometry, from employees during wellness checks. This alleged use of facial recognition technology is a primary issue in evaluating whether Amazon violated the Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA).

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual employee and class representative
parties.defendant_description: Corporate employer operating wellness check systems

claims.claim: Amazon collected employees’ biometric identifiers and information, including facial geometry, during wellness checks without obtaining informed written consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(b) – collection without informed written consent and disclosures.
claims.outcome: Court held allegations plausibly state a BIPA §15(b) claim and denied Amazon’s motion to dismiss this claim.

claims.claim: Amazon possessed and stored employees’ biometric data (facial geometry) without a publicly available written retention schedule and guidelines for permanent destruction.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(a) – lack of retention schedule and destruction policy.
claims.outcome: Court found plaintiff plausibly alleged a BIPA §15(a) violation and denied Amazon’s motion to dismiss this claim.

claims.claim: Amazon disclosed or otherwise disseminated employees’ biometric data to third parties, or allowed third-party access, without consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(d) – disclosure or dissemination without consent.
claims.outcome: Court concluded the complaint plausibly alleged potential dissemination of biometric data and denied Amazon’s motion to dismiss the BIPA §15(d) claim.

claims.claim: Amazon required employees to submit to facial scans as a condition of employment, thereby unlawfully conditioning employment on the collection of biometric data without BIPA-compliant procedures.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), generally §§15(a), 15(b), and 15(d), protecting against coerced, non-consensual biometric collection and use.
claims.outcome: Court treated these allegations as supporting the BIPA claims and held they were sufficient at the pleading stage, denying the motion to dismiss.

claims.claim: Class action claim on behalf of similarly situated employees subjected to the same biometric collection practices during wellness checks.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) class action provisions and Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23 (class certification sought later).
claims.outcome: At motion to dismiss stage, court allowed class allegations to proceed; no dismissal of class claims.

defenses.defense: The complaint fails to state a claim under BIPA because the alleged wellness checks and facial scans do not involve “biometric identifiers” or “biometric information” as defined by the statute.
defenses.legal_basis: Argument based on statutory definitions in BIPA, 740 ILCS 14/10, and Rule 12(b)(6) failure to state a claim.

defenses.defense: Even if data was collected, Amazon did not collect, possess, or disclose biometric data in a manner regulated by BIPA, so there is no statutory violation.
defenses.legal_basis: Interpretation of BIPA scope and elements; Rule 12(b)(6) dismissal standard.

defenses.defense: Any alleged dissemination or disclosure of biometric data is speculative and not plausibly alleged, so BIPA §15(d) claims should be dismissed.
defenses.legal_basis: Pleading sufficiency under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 8 and 12(b)(6).

defenses.defense: Plaintiff’s allegations regarding retention policies and destruction schedules are insufficiently specific to establish a violation of BIPA §15(a).
defenses.legal_basis: Pleading sufficiency under Rule 12(b)(6) and interpretation of BIPA §15(a) requirements.

case_id: 2022-07-25_USCOURTS-ilnd-1_21-cv-00135_In Re_ Clearview AI_ Inc._ Consumer Privacy Litigation.pdf
case_name: In re Clearview AI, Inc. Consumer Privacy Litigation
ai_relevance: Defendant allegedly used AI facial recognition algorithms on scraped online images to extract biometric identifiers without consent, central to BIPA claims.
ai_presence: The summary describes Clearview AI, Inc. as having "covertly scraped over three billion facial images from the internet and used AI algorithms to scan and extract biometric identifiers without consent, violating the Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA)." The case concerns Clearview’s use of "fancy computer programs"—i.e., artificial intelligence–driven facial recognition technology—to identify people from images and create a searchable database of biometric identifiers. The alleged misconduct is the deployment of AI-based facial recognition and biometric extraction tools on a massive scale without notice or consent, forming the core factual basis for the BIPA claims and the broader consumer privacy litigation.

parties.plaintiff_description: Putative class of individuals suing under BIPA
parties.defendant_description: Technology company and associated defendants in class action

claims.claim: Violation of the Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) by collecting, capturing, and obtaining biometric identifiers and information from facial images without informed written consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/1 et seq.
claims.outcome: Claims remain pending; court’s order addresses procedural issues and does not dismiss BIPA claims.

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA by failing to provide required written notice and publicly available retention and destruction policies for biometric data.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, including §§ 15(a) and 15(b).
claims.outcome: Claims remain pending; not dismissed in the reconsideration order.

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA by disclosing, redisclosing, or otherwise disseminating biometric identifiers and information to third parties without consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, including § 15(d).
claims.outcome: Claims remain pending; not dismissed in the reconsideration order.

claims.claim: Violation of BIPA by profiting from, or otherwise deriving commercial benefit from, biometric identifiers and information collected via facial recognition database.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, including § 15(c).
claims.outcome: Claims remain pending; not dismissed in the reconsideration order.

claims.claim: Class action claims seeking statutory damages, injunctive relief, and other remedies for Clearview’s alleged unlawful biometric data practices.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act and Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23 (class action mechanism).
claims.outcome: Class claims continue; court’s order denies defendants’ reconsideration motion and does not strike or dismiss class allegations.

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction over certain defendants, arguing the court cannot exercise jurisdiction.
defenses.legal_basis: Constitutional due process limits on personal jurisdiction; Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(2).

defenses.defense: Lack of Article III standing, asserting plaintiffs did not suffer a concrete injury sufficient for federal jurisdiction.
defenses.legal_basis: Article III of the U.S. Constitution; standing doctrine as interpreted by federal courts.

defenses.defense: Government-contractor exemption under BIPA, arguing that Clearview’s activities are exempt when performed for government or law-enforcement clients.
defenses.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act’s government-contractor or government-related exemption provisions.

defenses.defense: Arguments raised belatedly in a motion for reconsideration, attempting to re-argue or newly argue personal jurisdiction, standing, and BIPA exemption issues.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 54(b) or the court’s inherent authority to reconsider interlocutory orders; local rules governing motions for reconsideration.

case_name: Gutierrez v. Wemagine.AI LLP
ai_relevance: Dispute concerns Voila AI Artist app that uses AI to transform user photos, allegedly collecting biometric facial data without BIPA-compliant consent.
ai_presence: The case involves Wemagine.AI LLP’s mobile application, “Voila AI Artist,” described as an app that turns user photos into cartoon-like images. The app’s name and functionality indicate the use of artificial intelligence to process and transform facial images, which allegedly results in the collection and storage of users’ facial geometry and biometric identifiers without proper consent under the Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual Illinois user and class representative
parties.defendant_description: Canadian company operating Voila AI Artist app

claims.claim: Violation of the Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) by collecting, capturing, and storing users’ facial geometry and biometric identifiers through the Voila AI Artist app without obtaining informed written consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act, 740 ILCS 14/1 et seq.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for lack of personal jurisdiction; court did not reach the merits of the alleged BIPA violation.

claims.claim: Class action claim seeking to represent a class of Illinois residents whose biometric data was allegedly collected and stored via the Voila AI Artist app without BIPA-compliant disclosures and consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act and Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23 (class action mechanism).
claims.outcome: Effectively dismissed without prejudice when the entire action was dismissed for lack of personal jurisdiction over Wemagine.AI LLP.

defenses.defense: The court lacks personal jurisdiction over Wemagine.AI LLP because it is a Canadian company that did not purposefully direct its business activities or targeted marketing toward Illinois; any contacts with Illinois arose solely from users’ unilateral decision to download and use the app.
defenses.legal_basis: Constitutional due process limits on specific personal jurisdiction under the Fourteenth Amendment and applicable federal personal jurisdiction doctrine.

case_id: 2025-07-25_USCOURTS-ilsd-3_22-cv-00046_Lewis v. Maverick Transportation LLC et al.pdf
case_name: Lewis v. Maverick Transportation LLC et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on Lytx DriveCam’s machine-vision and AI system allegedly collecting and storing drivers’ biometric data without consent, in violation of Illinois’ Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA).
ai_presence: The case involves allegations that Lytx used machine vision and artificial intelligence (AI) in its DriveCam devices to predict distracted driving behaviors, collecting and storing biometric data without consent, in violation of Illinois' Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA).

parties.plaintiff_description: Class of drivers using Lytx DriveCam-equipped vehicles
parties.defendant_description: Trucking company and DriveCam technology provider

claims.claim: Defendants collected, captured, or obtained drivers’ biometric identifiers and information through Lytx DriveCam systems without first obtaining informed written consent.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(b) – notice and written consent requirements for collection of biometric identifiers/information.
claims.outcome: Resolved by class action settlement; court granted final approval and dismissed claims with prejudice in exchange for monetary relief from a $4.25 million settlement fund and other agreed terms.

claims.claim: Defendants stored and maintained drivers’ biometric data obtained via AI-enabled DriveCam systems without implementing required retention schedules or destruction policies and without proper disclosure.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(a) – publicly available retention schedule and guidelines for permanent destruction of biometric identifiers/information.
claims.outcome: Resolved by class action settlement; court approved settlement as fair, reasonable, and adequate and ordered implementation of agreed terms, including compensation to class members.

claims.claim: Defendants disclosed or otherwise made drivers’ biometric data available to third parties without consent, through operation and management of the Lytx DriveCam platform.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(d) – prohibition on disclosure or dissemination of biometric identifiers/information without consent or statutory authorization.
claims.outcome: Resolved by class action settlement; no adjudication on the merits, claims dismissed with prejudice upon final approval of settlement.

claims.claim: Defendants profited from or derived commercial benefit from drivers’ biometric data collected via the AI-enabled DriveCam system without complying with BIPA’s requirements.
claims.legal_basis: Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA), 740 ILCS 14/15(c) – prohibition on selling, leasing, trading, or otherwise profiting from biometric identifiers/information.
claims.outcome: Resolved by class action settlement; court’s final approval order implemented monetary relief and dismissed the action with prejudice.

defenses.defense: The proposed class action settlement is fair, reasonable, and adequate, and provides meaningful relief to class members compared to the risks, costs, and delay of continued litigation.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(e) standards for settlement approval; general class action settlement jurisprudence on fairness, reasonableness, and adequacy.

defenses.defense: Defendants deny liability and any violation of BIPA but agree to settle to avoid the burden, expense, and uncertainty of further litigation.
defenses.legal_basis: Standard no-admission-of-liability clause in class action settlements; contractual settlement principles.

case_name: Spilsbury v. Demchok et al.
ai_relevance: Plaintiff alleges defendants exploited her using artificial intelligence, including creating an online gaming account in her name and selling her identity on the dark web using AI-enabled tools.
ai_presence: "Spilsbury alleges that the defendants exploited her using artificial intelligence by creating an account in her name on an online gaming platform and selling her identity on the dark web, among other claims."

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual civil-rights plaintiff
parties.defendant_description: Individual defendants allegedly exploiting plaintiff

claims.claim: Civil rights violations through exploitation of her identity using artificial intelligence, including creating an online gaming account in her name and selling her identity on the dark web.
claims.legal_basis: 42 U.S.C. § 1983 (federal civil rights statute requiring deprivation of rights under color of state law).
claims.outcome: No final ruling on merits; court ordered plaintiff to amend and show cause why the claim should not be dismissed for failure to state a § 1983 claim and jurisdictional defects.

claims.claim: General civil rights complaint alleging deprivation of federally protected rights by private individuals.
claims.legal_basis: 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and federal-question jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. § 1331.
claims.outcome: Court found current allegations insufficient; granted leave to amend within 21 days to attempt to cure deficiencies or face dismissal.

defenses.defense: Defendants are private parties and did not act under color of state law, so § 1983 does not apply.
defenses.legal_basis: Requirement under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 that defendants act under color of state law; court’s sua sponte screening for failure to state a claim.

defenses.defense: Federal court lacks jurisdiction or must abstain because related or ongoing state court proceedings are addressing the same or related issues.
defenses.legal_basis: Younger abstention doctrine and Rooker-Feldman doctrine limiting federal review of state proceedings and judgments; raised by the court in its order to show cause.

case_name: Risher v. Adecco Inc. et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on text messages sent by AI-operated recruiting chatbot Mya and whether such AI-generated texts fall under TCPA’s artificial or prerecorded voice provisions.
ai_presence: The case involves an AI-operated chatbot named Mya, used by defendants to send recruiting-related text messages to consumers. Plaintiff alleges that Mya is an automated, conversational chatbot that interacts with users via text, mimicking human conversation, and that defendants used this AI system to send unsolicited text messages without prior consent. The court’s analysis addresses whether text messages generated and sent by this AI chatbot qualify as calls made using an “artificial or prerecorded voice” under the TCPA, ultimately concluding that such texts do not constitute a “voice” within the meaning of the statute.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual consumer and class representative
parties.defendant_description: Corporate job placement and recruiting companies

claims.claim: Defendants violated the TCPA by sending unsolicited text messages using an automatic telephone dialing system (autodialer).
claims.legal_basis: Telephone Consumer Protection Act, 47 U.S.C. § 227(b)(1)(A) – prohibition on calls made using an automatic telephone dialing system without prior express consent.
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court held that the system used did not meet the statutory definition of an autodialer in light of Supreme Court precedent limiting autodialers to systems that use a random or sequential number generator.

claims.claim: Defendants violated the TCPA by sending unsolicited text messages that used an artificial or prerecorded voice through the AI chatbot Mya.
claims.legal_basis: Telephone Consumer Protection Act, 47 U.S.C. § 227(b)(1)(A) – prohibition on calls to cell phones using an artificial or prerecorded voice without prior express consent.
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court held that text messages, even if generated by an AI chatbot, do not constitute calls made using an “artificial or prerecorded voice” because “voice” refers to audible, spoken communications, not written text messages.
